problemStatement.plain: Legendre's conjecture states that there is always a prime between consecutive perfect squares. We verify this computationally for n = 1 to 20.

proven: Verified for n = 1 to 20 with explicit prime witnesses

knowledge.progressSummary: Verified Legendre's conjecture for n = 1 to 20 using native_decide with explicit prime witnesses. Each case proven by providing a prime p with n^2 < p < (n+1)^2.

builtItems.name: LegendreAt
builtItems.description: Legendre's conjecture holds for specific n

insights: Proof pattern: use existential with explicit witness, verify with native_decide
native_decide checks primality, lower bound, and upper bound automatically
Bertrand's postulate doesn't help - gives prime in (n, 2n) which is too weak
Gap (n+1)^2 - n^2 = 2n+1 grows linearly, so prime density decreases slowly
mathlibGaps: No Legendre conjecture formalization in Mathlib
nextSteps: Consider automation to generate witness primes

approaches.name: Computational verification
approaches.hypothesis: Can verify small cases with native_decide
approaches.strategy: Provide explicit prime witnesses, verify computationally
